review_title: A Decent Workplace Minus Authoritarian Managers and a Greedy CEO
job_title: Anonymous Employee in La Crosse, WI
pros: Most of your co-workers are truly kind and easy to have a good relationship with. Extensive training ensures you are well-prepared for your job. The opportunity to help individuals navigate the labyrinth of the United States' healthcare system can be emotionally rewarding.
cons: Authoritarian managers too often micromanage and crack down on your personal autonomy (e.g., cell phone use on break time, can only use paid time off for days off). The CEO gives off the veneer of a kind old doctor but does not really care about his employees. This is reflected in the fact that this organization is a multimillion-dollar system that is actively trying to merge with Bellin Health, but then states that Gundersen cannot "afford" to increase benefits to their employees. Asinine policies that are not fully justified beyond, "Well, we have to do this because of the Joint Commission."

job_title: Purchasing Agent in West Salem, WI

job_title: Supply Chain in London, England
pros: Exceptional retirement plan that includes employee contribution, employer-matching contribution, plus an annual "bonus" employer contribution if the organization does well for the year.
cons: Expensive employer-sponsored health insurance plans, poor pay, extremely poor leadership across the board from top-down. Extremely unequal treatment and pay from one employee to the next. Some are required to have 4yr. degrees for their jobs, others aren't. Some are allowed to work remotely from home, others aren't. Some are required to work a minimum of 45 hours per week, but the person sitting next to you with the exact same time is lucky to put 7 hours in a day. If you are looking for support, mentorship, good benefits, a good work-home life balance, do not work here.

It's they way it is."; If you get sick and have to go to the doctors or the ER either during one of your shifts or instead of your shift, apparently management knows better and that doctor's note to stay home and rest doesn't count as an excuse to leave/be gone;

job_title: CNA in La Crosse, WI
pros: It's an easy job, but that isn't necessarily a good thing. You will have opportunities to learn about people and to work in a modern facility. It's a comfortable job for nurses.
cons: Although some people get better on their own, outside of acute surgical interventions, the hospital itself is almost totally ineffective. Your soul will wither and die watching the hospital drain every bit of money they can justify from the savings and insurance policies of the injured and diseased. Meanwhile, two faced employees who do the least amount of work possible get the most respect from their coworkers and superiors. Doctors and specialists are quite busy. Everyone below the nurses is really looked down on. The culture is self congratulatory. Nearly everyone is too fearful to rock the boat and push for improvement because that would mean admitting that they are not already doing the best they can. If someone has a complaint, your coworkers will lie to protect themselves and they will lie to pin the blame on you if it will benefit them.

job_title: Accounts Receivable in La Crosse, WI

job_title: Medical Coder in Madison, WI

cons: Inflexible, low pay, high insurance deductible

review_title: I worked there for 20 years and lost my job.  Worst department in Gundersen...Transcription
job_title: Medical Transcriptionist in Onalaska, WI
pros: Pay was great.  Benefits were okay, getting less and less as the years went on.  Early on in my career there it was great!  Fun staff to work with and very flexible.
cons: The transcription department specifically at Gundersen Lutheran was very inflexible and treated us a factory workers instead of educated individuals work with confidential and important medical information.  It was production, production, production and no care for quality.  No other department within that system works this way.  They have now eliminated most of the transcriptionists and are outsourcing their work to a transcription company.  All very money oriented.

job_title: IS Support Specialist I in La Crosse, WI
pros: The entire IS department seemed to have everybody's best interest in mind.  The atmosphere was great, and people really worked hard.  Rewards were given when due, and people seemed to be judged by their performance.  The people running my team had cut their teeth doing my job.  When things became hectic, they helped, which isn't often seen in a system as large as Gundersen.  It was the best full time working experience of my life, and I was there for 5 years, before having to relocate across the country.
cons: Benefits were chopped while I was there.  The pension disappeared, and the insurance covered less and less with each passing year.

job_title: Central Service Technician in La Crosse, WI
pros: Co-workers. Health insurance ok in the beginning, got worse when they started cutting cost. Clean environment.  Good brand. Good for your CV
cons: Salary increments almost non-existent. Few Managers are trained in being proper leaders. Doctors and OR staff think too highly of theirselves. I am sure their arms will fall off soon from all the patting of their own backs they do. God forbid u owe the hospital money for your own family's medical care, they will take u to court and garnish your wages. No offer to even deduct the amount U owe from your salary. Nope, they would rather take u to court.

job_title: Patient Lias in Viroqua, WI
pros: I was at GHS as a patient liaison in one of the regional clinics. Benefits and pay were exceptional for a front desk position. GHS is open to listening to employees and making a happy, healthy work environment. I was only there a year and a half before moving out of state, but it was clear to me that GHS wants to grow employee skills and strengthen their work force.
cons: Communication internally was not always clear at the regional clinic  and system-wide. Several changes took place without clarity for staff. Regional clinics admin staff struggle to keep up with the changes that take place at the LAX and ONA clinics.

job_title: Administrative Director, Medical/Surgical Services in La Crosse, WI
pros:
Lots of advancement opportunities with clinics and hospital locations
Good benefits
Nice people to work with
Beautiful facilities, especially new hospital
cons:
Parking is horrible, especially in winter. Also no parking at main campus for people who come in for meetings and have to leave again. End up spending 15 minutes just getting from the parking lot to the hospital/clinic. 
Cafeteria is awful. Only offer "healthy" options and therefore no burgers or fries. No chocolate to be found in hospital as they changed the vending machines to healthy treats only. Both staff and families want a treat now and then but you better plan for it.

review_title: Flashes of excellence marred by chronic mediocrity
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in La Crosse, WI
pros: Lower than average nurse to patient ratios throughout the hospital. Reasonable attempts to keep up to date with technology. Good equipment. Most nurses are competent and strive to provide great care. The nursing staff are what keep it worth sticking around. The unit level managers really do care about their staff and try to do what they can to improve retention. Non-salary benefits are adequate.
cons: You really are a number when you're an RN at Gundersen. Members of clinical management once informed us there are three nursing schools nearby and you can easily be replaced if you don't like the way things are. There are no incentives to perform beyond mediocrity aside from being shouldering additional committee/project work. The pay is not competitive (~$5+ an hour deficit) with other organizations that draw nurses from the region like Mayo, UW Health and the Twin Cities organizations.  Experience isn't consistently a benefit when you come from another organization in terms of pay. Everyone gets the same raises across the board year after year creating a wage stagnation issue for staff (but a boon for the organization). Problem employees are moved around departments until people stop bringing concerns to management.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Onalaska, WI
pros: Decent retirement with a company match on investment.
cons: This company provides a good healthcare service to its patients. However if you are an employee in a role other than provider or nurse, they leave a lot to be desired. Management is overworked and underpaid and it filters down. A conservative oriented company whose employees would benefit greatly and in many ways from increased government regulations. Board of directors and many providers who control much of the business are ultra conservative which I believe hurts all of those underneath them.

review_title: Exceptional, patient-focused clinic which values employees.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in La Crosse, WI
pros: This company really has it all together. I feel valued as an employee and I feel that every patient receives fantastic healthcare. It is satisfying to know that I contribute to such an excellent team. Jeff Thompson, CEO, has stopped to talk to me (a nobody) on multiple occasions just to check in and see how things are going. He parks in the regular employee parking lot, which impressed me.
cons: It is a bit small town. Sometimes I worry that promotions are based on who you know.

review_title: This is how health care should be managed.
job_title: Staff Physician in La Crosse, WI
pros: Strong commitment to evidence-based care, standardization of best practices, and teamwork. Competitive salaries with recognition of extra effort. Integrated health system with excellent implementation of EHR.
cons: It's in western Wisconsin - there's not much in the way of culture here and the population is pretty homogenous. Some services, while needed (as there's nothing else for miles around) have low volume, making skills hard to keep up and staffing hard to manage.

job_title: Clinic RN in La Crosse, WI
pros: The company motto is "excellence" and I believe this is a commitment of all employees from the CEO and administration to management, clinic and hospital staff. I worked there for 8 years and learned a lot about how leadership can be executed well and how to involve employees who do the work in shared decision-making.
cons: All companies have there ups and downs, growing pains and individuals with bad attitudes, but Gundersen strives to care for individuals as well as the whole company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Onalaska, WI
pros: Good benefits, many opportunities for lateral movement to gain experience, coworker relationships, above average pay for the area
cons: Managers who work hard and care about their teams and their customers are severely and consistently overworked, while underperforming leaders are tolerated and frequently thrive.  Senior leadership is out of touch with what is happening on the front lines, particularly with respect to middle management.

job_title: Registration Specialist in La Crosse, WI
pros: They seemed to be family oriented, have pretty decent pay and benefits to offer along with internal opportunities once you were a permanent employee
cons: Cost of family insurance benefits high, need to have longer training for each position instead of trying to do it with too many people in to short of time

job_title: in Onalaska, WI
pros: Gundersen Health System staff provides high quality health care.  The staff is very patient-focused and management focuses on quality and service.  It is one of the larger employers in a small market.
cons: The organization has experienced a number of changes due to public policy and internal strategy.  Change can be difficult for a medium-large size organization.

job_title: in La Crosse, WI
pros: Up to 15% employer contribution to 401k/yr. great vacation and pay.  Yearly raises, 4.5 weeks vacation starting. One of the nations top 50 hospitals.
cons: A lot of management/meetings, this sometimes will put strain on departments.  Sometimes the organization can be reactive instead of proactive. Overall I am satisfied with this company.

job_title: Environmental Assistant in Lacrosse, WA
pros:
You make friends who are Medical Doctors and Registered Nurses,

Greats connections at the Lacrosse Wisconsin location
cons: Rare upward mobility, and if you are an Environmental Assistant, (top 10 most significant position) most of the staff see you as trash at the Lacrosse Wisconsin

review_title: Being a good employee and serving for many years means absolutely nothing.
job_title: BUSINESS SERVICES--Revenue Cycle in Onalaska, WI
pros: Pay is ok.  Benefits are ok but were better years ago.   Supervisors are ok to really good.  Management not so much.  Great co-workers/team members.  Patient care is of the highest importance. Recently I have been working with an awesome team with an awesome supervisor in a job I really like.
cons: No matter how good your reviews are and no matter how many years you have dedicated to the organization, in the end you are just a number that can be replaced without a thought.   They will take you from a position you like and move you into a place you hate because they can't fill it and without even asking for volunteers.  This has happened to me 3 times and has just happened again. The higher ups don't really care if employees are happy in their positions or if the employee is even capable of doing a good job in that position they've moved them to,which to me is setting you up for failure.  I would think an employer would want to put people into positions they like and are motivated to do well at., that's why people apply for certain positions in the first place.  Right now they are taking away all of what my department does,dispersing it to other areas and making us into a completely different department with very different job duties and  hours that none of us want.  We all really loved what we were doing and now we all just hate coming to work. And if you can't do the hours or the work their answer is to bad, find a different job.
